title: 109_s2655
content: The "Credit Card Reform Act of 2006" prohibits universal default and unilateral changes to cardholder agreements. Chapter 4 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to prohibit credit card issuers from using adverse information to increase interest rates on credit card accounts. Exceptions apply for certain circumstances. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits credit card issuers from using adverse information to increase interest rates on credit card accounts, with exceptions for specific circumstances. The limitation must be clearly disclosed to consumers by the issuer. Additionally, credit card issuers are prohibited from unilaterally changing the terms of a credit card agreement. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits credit card issuers from unilaterally changing the terms of a credit card agreement without the consumer's specific written consent. Cardholders have the right to repay existing balances under the terms in effect when the balances were incurred. Termination of an account due to failure to agree to a change in terms does not constitute a default or trigger immediate repayment of the obligation. SEC. 3. CAP ON FEES CHARGED BY CREDITORS. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to include limitations on late payment fees for credit card accounts under open end consumer credit plans. Credit card issuers must clearly state the payment due date and late payment fee on billing statements to avoid penalties. The Truth in Lending Act limits late payment fees for credit card accounts. Card issuers cannot impose fees or raise rates if payment is postmarked by the due date. Fees imposed must be reasonable and related to the issuer's costs. The Truth in Lending Act limits late payment fees for credit card accounts, ensuring fees are reasonable and related to the issuer's costs. Amendments are made to sections of the Act to remove outdated provisions. The Truth in Lending Act limits late payment fees for credit card accounts, ensuring fees are reasonable and related to the issuer's costs. Amendments are made to sections of the Act to remove outdated provisions. Universal defaults are prohibited and there is a cap on fees. Verification of ability to pay credit obligations is required. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to require credit card issuers to verify a consumer's ability to pay before opening a new account or increasing credit limits. The Board will establish regulations for determining this ability based on income, obligations, and employment status. The Board will prohibit unfair, deceptive, or evasive acts in connection with credit card accounts under open-end consumer credit plans, as well as those associated with abusive lending practices or not in the consumer's interest. The amendments made by this Act will take effect 6 months after enactment, with the Board starting to propose regulations to implement the amendments on or after the enactment date.
